"5Product and Solution & Website Business Unit, Alibaba Cloud, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China {xjj20, leijs20, yangli21}@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn, 19801212354@163.com, {qiujian.qj, luobiao.luo, xiaolei.xiao, zhoubo.zww}@alibaba-inc.com  *Corresponding author     Abstract  Carbon capture and storage (CCS) offers a promising means for significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions and climate change mitigation at a large scale. Modeling CO2 transport and pressure buildup is central to understanding the responses of geosystems after CO2 injection and assessing the suitability and safety of CO2 storage. However, numerical simulations of geological CO2 storage often suffer from its multi-physics nature and complex non-linear governing equations, and is further complicated by flexible injection de-signs including changes in injection rates, resulting in formi-dable computational costs. New ideas have emerged such as data-driven models to tackle such challenges but very few have been fully developed and deployed as reliable tools. With the joint efforts of industry and universities, we are cur-rently working on a new mechanism of fostering cross-disci-plinary collaboration, developing, deploying, and scaling data-driven tools for CCS. A deep learning suite that can act as an alternative to CCS variable rate injection simulation will be the first tool developed under this mechanism. Based on the surrogate model, optimal design of injection strategy under pressure buildup constraints will be enabled with ma-chine learning. The 5Product and Solution & Website Business Unit of Alibaba Cloud, located in Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China, is working on a new mechanism for fostering cross-disciplinary collaboration to develop, deploy, and scale data-driven tools for carbon capture and storage (CCS). The team is currently developing a deep learning suite that can serve as an alternative to CCS variable rate injection simulation. This tool will enable optimal design of injection strategy under pressure buildup constraints using machine learning.

Geological storage of CO2 in saline aquifers, depleted oil and gas fields, or unmineable coal seams is a crucial process for reducing anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases. The International Energy Agency's (IEA) Sustainable Development Scenario proposes that over 90% of CO2 captured from various sectors and sources should be stored geologically through 2070. CO2 storage in deep saline aquifers is a vital option, with an estimated global capacity of 10^3-10^4 gigatons.

Successful CO2 storage projects rely on accurate prediction of geo-sequestration processes, taking into account specific reservoir conditions and injection configurations. Numerical simulation is the primary tool used for predicting CO2 flow transport by solving conservation equations. However, this process is governed by highly non-linear partial differential equations (PDEs) and requires fine spatial and temporal discretization for accurate depiction of flow processes. As a result, large-scale numerical simulation is computationally expensive, inefficient, and even infeasible for some CCS storage optimization problems.

Machine learning has shown potential for applications to CCS problems as a substitute for conventional numerical simulation, offering comparable fidelity at a much faster speed. For example, a rough set-based machine learning technique was used to test the storage integrity of geological reservoirs. Support vector machine (SVM) and random forest (RF) algorithms were also applied to predict CO2 trapping efficiencies in saline formations. In more complicated cases, machine learning and deep learning methods can directly model typical outputs from numerical simulators, such as CO2 saturation distributions and pressure responses.

Recent advances include CCSNet, a temporal 3D CNN model architecture that predicts dynamic changes in CO2 storage processes in deep saline aquifers for single well injection scenarios with constant injection rates. A Fourier neural operator-based deep-learning model (U-FNO) was also proposed to address the effect of reservoir anisotropy on CO2 storage under simplified CO2 injection configurations.

In industrial-scale carbon sequestration operations, injection designs, such as injection rate, injection scenario, well configuration, and perforation interval, play a central role in determining CO2 storage capacity, risks, and liabilities, and ultimately the environmental and economic benefits of a project. For example, excessive pressure buildup can lead to CO2 leakage and other safety risks.
